title: PCT 09: Sweet-Grass Defeats the Blackfoot and Sarsi
author: Coming-Day

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-ayâcik wîkiwâhk, wawêyiwak, êh-sipwêhtêcik, ayahciyiniwah êh-ntonawâcik, ê-wîh-kakwêh-kimotamawâcik otêmiyiwah, ahpôh pêyakoyicih ê-wîh-nipahâcik ayahciyiniwah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-ayâcik wîkiwâhk wawêyîwak ê-sipwêhtêcik ayahciyiniwa ê-nitonawâcik ê-wî-kakwê-kimotamawâcik otêmiyiwa ahpô pêyakoyici ê-wî-nipahâcik ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: Once upon a time some people got ready and went forth to look for Blackfoot, to try to steal their horses from them, or, if one was alone, to kill the Blackfoot.
That was their purpose.

sentences.original: sipwêhtêwak; mitâtaht ayênâniwosâp ihtasiwak nêhiyawak ôkih, oskinîkiwak.
sentences.text: sipwêhtêwak mitâtaht ayinânêwosâp ihtasiwak nêhiyawak ôki oskinîkiwak
sentences.english: They set out; eighteen was the number of these Cree, young men.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê sîpiy êh-otihtahkik, êkotah êh-kapêsicik, ê-wîh-nipâcik tipiskâkih,
sentences.text: kîtahtawê sîpiy ê-otihtahkik êkota ê-kapêsicik ê-wî-nipâcik tipiskâki
sentences.english: In time, when they came to a stream, they made camp there, to sleep that night.
When night came, there was frost, and snow fell.
Dawn came; it snowed.
“Now go hunt,” they said to the young men;
“When the storm ceases we shall go on.
If you kill a buffalo, we shall not go hungry.”

sentences.original: tâpwêh pêyak oskinîkiw pasikôw, êh-sipwêhtêt, ê-wîh-kakwêh-wâpamât mostoswah, êh-mâcît.
sentences.text: tâpwê pêyak oskinîkiw pasikôw ê-sipwêhtêt ê-wî-kakwê-wâpamât mostoswa ê-mâcît
sentences.english: So a youth arose and set out to look for buffalos, to hunt.
There as he walked along, he caught sight of a lone Blackfoot.
He came back to his companions.

sentences.original: êh-takohtêt ômisi itêw : niwâpamâw ayahciyiniw êh-pêyakot, itêw.
sentences.english: When he got there he said, “I saw a lone Blackfoot,” he told them.
Accordingly they made ready to try to kill the Blackfoot;
they set out one after the other and went to the place where the  Blackfoot had been seen.
When they were close by, they saw him driving home horses.
They attacked him, to rob him of his horses.

sentences.original: awah ê-wâpamât nêhiyawah ayahciyiniw, tapasîw, êh-sipwêtisahwât misatimwah.
sentences.text: awa ê-wâpamât nêhiyawa ayahciyiniw tapasîw ê-sipwêtisahwât misatimwa
sentences.english: When the Blackfoot saw the Cree, he fled, driving on the horses.

sentences.original: êh-pimipahtât, kisiwâk sîpiy ayâyiw, êkotah ê-pinasiwêtisahwât ôhi misatimwah.
sentences.text: ê-pimipahtât kisiwâk sîpiy ayâyiw êkota ê-pinasiwêtisahwât ôhi misatimwa
sentences.english: As he ran along, a river was near there; down to it he drove the horses.
That was the camping-place of those Blackfoot.

sentences.original: êkotah ê-sâkêwêcik tah sîpiyihk nêhiyawak, kâ-wâpahtahkik mîkiwâhpah.
sentences.text: êkota ê-sâkêwêcik ita sîpiyihk nêhiyawak kâ-wâpahtahkik mîkiwâhpa
sentences.english: When the Cree came out upon the river, there they saw the tents.
The Cree fled.

sentences.original: wawêyiwak iyahciyiniwak, êh-têhtapicik otêmiwâwa, êh-nawaswâtâcik ôhih nêhiyawah.
sentences.text: wawêyîwak ayahciyiniwak ê-têhtapicik otêmiwâwa ê-nawaswâtâcik ôhi nêhiyawa
sentences.english: The Blackfoot got ready and mounted their horses, and pursued the Cree.

sentences.original: ê-pmpahtâcik nêhiyawak, kotak êh-pasahcâyik ê-sakâyik êkotah êh-itohtêcik, kâ-wâpahtahkik kotakah mîkiwâhpah.
sentences.text: ê-pimipahtâcik nêhiyawak kotak ê-pasahcâyik ê-sakâyik êkota ê-itohtêcik kâ-wâpahtahkik kotaka mîkiwâhpa
sentences.english: As the Cree, in their flight, came to another wooded gully, there they saw some other tents.
These people too were Blackfoot.
From here again they fled.
These people, too, attacked them.
By this time the others were many, and of them therefore only eighteen.
They saw a spruce-grove; they fled into it.

sentences.original: hâw, oskinîkîtik, wâtihkêk, itwêwak okih nêhiyawak.
sentences.english: “Come, young men, dig a trench,” said the Cree.
By this time the Blackfoot were all around.
Now they began to be shot at; and they, too, shot at the others.
So they fought each other.

sentences.original: wâtihkêwak mistah ôkô ôskinîkiwak, êkotah êh-apicik wâtihk.
sentences.text: wâtihkêwak mistahi ôki oskinîkiwak êkota ê-apicik wâtihk
sentences.english: Those young men dug a large trench, and they stayed in the trench.

sentences.original: ômisi isiyîhkâtêw omah wâtihkân : mênisk isiyîhkâtêw.
sentences.english: Such a trench is called “earthwork.”

sentences.original: ôkih k-âyimisicik êyôkonik ômis îsiyîhkâsôwak : êh-nâpêhkâsocik isiyihkâsôwak, namoya êh-pîhtokêcik wâtihkânihk, êyôkonik êh-âhkamêyimocik êh-nôtinikêcik.
sentences.text: ôki kâ-âyimisicik êwakonik ômisi isiyîhkâsôwak isiyîhkâsôwak namôya ê-pîhtokêcik wâtihkânihk êwakonik ê-âhkamêyimocik ê-nôtinikêcik
sentences.english: The men who fight so as to be feared are called “braves,” those who do not go into the pit but courageously fight.
They fought for a long time.
At last night came.

sentences.original: êh-tipiskâyik, kotakah mînah takosiniyiwah ayahciyiniwah, êkonih mînah êh-nôtinikocik.
sentences.text: ê-tipiskâyik kotaka mîna takosiniyiwa ayahciyiniwa êkoni mîna ê-nôtinikocik
sentences.english: At nightfall some more Blackfoot arrived, and these too joined in the fight against the Cree.

sentences.original: piyis wâsakâm êkotah kotawêyiwah, êkâh ta-sipwêhtêcik, êh-itêyimikocik.
sentences.english: Finally they built fires all around, intending to bring it about that the Cree should not leave that place.
At last day dawned.
They did not sleep for fighting.
By now they had killed many Blackfoot;

sentences.original: wiyawâw nama kêkway nipahikwak ôkih nêhiyawak.
sentences.text: wiyawâw nama kêkway nipahikwak ôki nêhiyawak
sentences.english: the latter had killed none of the Cree.

sentences.original: piyisk ê-sâkâstêyik, kotakah mînah takohtêyiwah êh-pêh-nâh-nâtamâtôyit, êh-pê-wîcihitoyit, ê-wîh-kakwêh-mêscihikocik.
sentences.text: piyisk ê-sâkâstêyik kotaka mîna takohtêyiwa ê-pê-nâh-nâtamâtoyit ê-pê-wîcihitoyit ê-wî-kakwê-mêscihikocik
sentences.english: When daylight came, again some other Blackfoot arrived, to relieve the others, and help them try to massacre the Cree.

sentences.original: mâkah nama kêkway nipahikwak; cêskwah wiyawâw mihcêt nipahêwak.
sentences.text: mâka nama kêkway nipahikwak cêskwa wiyawâw mihcêt nipahêwak
sentences.english: But they killed none at all of the Cree, while the latter killed many of them.

sentences.original: êwakô kapê-kîsik nôtinitôwak, piyisk ê-wîh-tipiskâk, nistoh pikoh nôtinikêwak nêhiyawak.
sentences.text: êwako kapê-kîsik nôtinitôwak piyisk ê-wî-tipiskâk nisto piko nôtinikêwak nêhiyawak
sentences.english: They fought all that day, until, toward nightfall, only three of the Cree were still fighting.

sentences.original: ômisi isiyîhkâsôw awa nêhiyaw k-âyimisit êh-nôtinikêt : wîhkasko-kisêyin isiyihkâsôw.
sentences.text: ômisi isiyîhkâsôw awa nêhiyaw kâ-âyimisit ê-nôtinikêt wîhkasko-kisêyin isiyîhkâsôw
sentences.english: This was the name of the Cree who fought most redoubtably: Sweet-Grass was his name.
Another was called Big-Bear,

sentences.original: êkwah kotak napatê-kîsik isiyîhkâsôw; êwakô nôhtâwiy.
sentences.text: êkwa kotak napatê-kîsik isiyîhkâsôw êwako nôhtâwiy
sentences.english: and the other was called Half-sky; he was my father.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-tipiskâyik, âsay mînah kotakah takohtêyiwah iyahciyiniwah.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-tipiskâyik âsay mîna kotaka takohtêyiwa ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: Then, at night, still more Blackfoot arrived.
But by this time they had slain many Blackfoot.
Then, late in the night, Big-Bear got tired;

sentences.original: pîhtokêw wâtihkânihk, nîso-kîsikâw, kêkâc nîso-tipiskâw êh-nôtinikêt, kâ-nêstosit.
sentences.text: pîhtokêw wâtihkânihk nîso-kîsikâw kêkâc nîso-tipiskâw ê-nôtinikêt kâ-nêstosit
sentences.english: he went into the pit, wearied from having fought two days and almost two nights.
Then only two Cree were fighting.

sentences.original: wâsakâm kisiwâk êh-pêy-itohtêyit iyahciyiniwah, iskotêw êh-tahkonamiyit, êyak ôhci êh-pakamahokocik, kah-kakwêh-kîsisôwak, êh-itêyimikocik,
sentences.text: wâsakâm kisiwâk ê-pê-itohtêyit ayahciyiniwa iskotêw ê-tahkonamiyit êwako ohci ê-pakamahokocik ê-itêyimikocik
sentences.english: As the Blackfoot came close from all sides, bearing fire, with which they struck at the Cree, meaning to burn them,

sentences.original: piyisk, mistikwah wâsakâm ê-kîh-astâcik omêniskiwâhk, piyisk êwakonih saskitêyiwah;
sentences.text: piyisk mistikwa wâsakâm ê-kî-astâcik omêniskiwâhk piyisk êwakoni saskitêyiwa
sentences.english: at last the sticks which they had placed round their earthwork caught fire,
but the Cree were not burned.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê awah napatê-kîsik k-êsiyîhkâsot êwakô ospiskwanihk, ôhi otîhiyah êkotah, pahkihtiniyiw môsosiniy, ayahciyiniwah êh-pâskisokot;
sentences.text: kîtahtawê awa napatê-kîsik kâ-isiyîhkâsot êwako ospiskwanihk ôhi otîhiya êkota pahkihtiniyiw môsasiniy ayahciyiniwa ê-pâskisokot
sentences.english: Then at one time he whose name was Half-sky, a bullet hit him in the back, here at his shoulder-blade, as the  Blackfoot shot at him,

sentences.original: mâka namoya pîkopayiyiwah wasakayah, namoya ê-kîh-pikwahokot;
sentences.text: mâka namôya pîkopayiyiwa wasakaya namôya ê-kî-pikwâhokot
sentences.english: but his skin was not broken, he was not pierced by the bullet;
but the bone was broken.
So now he was not able to hold a gun.
He was not able to use his arm on that side.
So he ceased fighting;
now Sweet-Grass was alone in the fight.
At last the Blackfoot were quite near.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê wîhkaskô-kisêyin kâ-wâpamât kisiwâk mistikwah êh-cimasôyit, êkotah êh-pê-nahapiyit, êh-âkôsimoyit, ê-misikitiyit mistikwah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê wîhkasko-kisêyin kâ-wâpamât kisiwâk mistikwa ê-cimasoyit êkota ê-pê-nahapiyit ê-âkôsimoyit ê-misikitiyit mistikwa
sentences.english: Then, at one time, Sweet-Grass saw, where a tree stood close by, that a Blackfoot came and crouched near it, shielding himself behind it, behind the big tree.

sentences.original: êkotah ohci wâpamêw êh-pê-mihcêtiyit ôh îyahciyiniwah, êkwah ê-wîh-kakwêh-otihtinikocik owâtihkâniwâhk.
sentences.text: êkota ohci wâpamêw ê-pê-mihcêtiyit ôhi ayahciyiniwa êkwa ê-wî-kakwê-otihtinikocik owâtihkâniwâhk
sentences.english: On that side he saw the Blackfoot coming in numbers and making ready to storm them in their trench.

sentences.original: pôtih aw âyahciyiniw kâ-nîkânohtêt mistikohk k-âpit.
sentences.text: pôti awa ayahciyiniw kâ-nîkânohtêt mistikohk kâ-apit
sentences.english: There, by the tree, sat the Blackfoot who marched in the lead.

sentences.original: awah nêhiyaw itêh k-ôh-ayât êkotêh ohcih, awa mistik kayâs ês ê-kîh-kîsisot, wâpamêw ôhi mistikwah, êh-kîh-wâsahîhkasôyit.
sentences.text: awa nêhiyaw itê kâ-ôh-ayât êkotê ohci awa mistik kayâs êsa ê-kî-kîsisot wâpamêw ôhi mistikwa ê-kî-wâsahîhkasoyit
sentences.english: From where he was, that Cree saw that tree, and saw that it had of old been burned, struck by lightning.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah ôtah pâskiswêw mistikwah awa nêhiyaw.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa ôta pâskiswêw mistikwa awa nêhiyaw
sentences.english: So the Cree shot at the tree itself.
The  Blackfoot was pierced to the heart;
the bullet entered his breast;
he was killed.

sentences.original: êkosi ôhi otôskinîkîmah owîcêwâkanah kahkiyaw tapasiyiwah, êh-nipahiht êh-okimâwit aw âyahciyiniw.
sentences.text: êkosi ôhi otôskinîkîma owîcêwâkana kahkiyaw tapasîyiwa ê-nipahiht ê-okimâwit awa ayahciyiniw
sentences.english: Then his followers and companions all fled, when the Blackfoot chief was slain.
Thereupon they ceased firing; they ceased fighting.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kâ-matwê-pîkiskwêt aw âyahciyiniw êh-nêhiyawêt; awêniki kiyawâw ? êkosîy itwêw.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kâ-matwê-pîkiskwêt awa ayahciyiniw ê-nêhiyawêt êkosi itwêw
sentences.english: Then the Blackfoot called out, in Cree; “Who are you?” he asked.
“Cree.”
“I recognize some chiefs.”

sentences.original: êkosi ômisi itwêwak nêhiyawak : nam âwiyak okimâw ôtah, itwêwak nêhiyawak.
sentences.text: êkosi ômisi itwêwak nêhiyawak itwêwak nêhiyawak
sentences.english: Then thus answered the Cree: “There are no chiefs here,” they said.
To be sure, two of the Cree were chiefs.

sentences.original: wîhkaskô-kisêyin êwako pêyak okimâw; êkwah kotak mistahê-maskwah, êwako mînah okimâw;
sentences.text: wîhkasko-kisêyin êwako pêyak okimâw êkwa kotak mistahi-maskwa êwako mîna okimâw
sentences.english: Sweet-Grass was a chief, and Big-Bear also was a chief;
but they did not want to tell him this.

sentences.original: piyisk aw îyahciyiniw matwê-pikiskwêw, tân-tahtoh kinipahikawinâwâw, nêhiyâtik ? êkosi itwêw.
sentences.text: piyisk awa ayahciyiniw matwê-pîkiskwêw êkosi itwêw
sentences.english: Later the Blackfoot called; “How many of you have been slain, O Cree?” he asked.
“None at all,” answered the Cree.
sentences.footnote: KR:  Book has the three sentences of this paragraph on separate lines and indented as paragraphs, but with no paragraph number.

sentences.english: And in fact, none of the Cree had been killed.
“And you?” the Cree asked them.

sentences.original: ômisîy itwêw ayahciyiniw : têpakôhp mistahi êh-okimâwicik kaskitêwayastak kâ-nipahâyêkok;
sentences.english: Thus spoke the Blackfoot: “Seven great chiefs of the Blackfoot you have slain;
and six Blood chiefs you have slain;

sentences.original: êkwah sasîwak nêwo okimâwak kinipahâwâwak; êkwah pîkanôwîniwak nîso okimâwak.
sentences.english: and four Sarsi chiefs you have slain, and two Piegan chiefs.

sentences.original: namoya mihcêt ôtah ayâwak pîkanôwîniwak; mâkah ôki kotakak kâ-wâh-wîhakik, itôwahk mihcêt okimâwak kinipahâwâwak.
sentences.english: There are not many Piegans here, but of those whom I have named, of them you have killed many chieftains.
Now they will cease;
they fear you now.”
Thus spoke that Blackfoot.
Then really they did cease shooting at each other.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki nêhiyawak pêyak nâpêsis êkotah êh-wîcêwât, wâtihkânihk ê-kîh-apit awa nâpêsis, mahtih nika-wâpamâwak iyahciyiniwak, itwêw awa nâpêsis.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki nêhiyawak pêyak nâpêsis êkota ê-wîcêwât wâtihkânihk ê-kî-apit awa nâpêsis itwêw awa nâpêsis
sentences.english: And among those Cree a young lad who was with them and had stayed in the trench, “Let me go look at the Blackfoot,” said this  boy.
“Do not!” his comrades said to him.
Nevertheless he went out of the trench.
At once a shot rang out;
he reeled over, struck in the spine, the bone shattered.
They got him and laid him in the trench.

sentences.original: êkosi kâ-kîh-ititân; osâm namoya kipa-pêhtên, êh-itâcik ôhi nâpêsisah;
sentences.english: “This is what I told you; but you did not listen,” they told him;
“If you had obeyed, you would not have been wounded,” they said to him.
Then they stopped.
The Blackfoot went home.

sentences.original: êkwah nêhiyawak ay-apiwak êkotah, mâskôc tâpwêh kipônihikonawak, êh-itwêcik.
sentences.english: The Cree stayed there, saying, “Perhaps they really have given us up.”

sentences.original: kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw, mahtih nka-wâpamâwak; mahti tâpwê kê-kîwêcik, êh-itwêt, ê-sipwêhtêt.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw ê-itwêt ê-sipwêhtêt
sentences.english: Presently one man said, “Let me go look at them; suppose they really will turn out to have gone home,” said he and departed.
He did not see them; he came back.

sentences.original: nôhtêyâpâkwêwak, nîso-kîsikâw nîso-tipiskâw êkâh êh-minihkwêcik, êkâh êh-mîcisocik, namoya êh-nipâcik.
sentences.text: nôhtêyâpâkwêwak nîso-kîsikâw nîso-tipiskâw êkâ ê-minihkwêcik êkâ ê-mîcisocik namôya ê-nipâcik
sentences.english: They were thirsty, not having drunk for two days and nights, and having neither eaten nor slept.
So they got up to go away.

sentences.original: ê-wîh-nakasiyêk cî ? êkos îtwêw awa nâpêsis.
sentences.english: “And are you going to leave me?” asked that boy.
For he was not able to walk.
“No,” his companions answered him;
It is only that we are thirsty.

sentences.original: miskamâhkô nipiy ka-pê-nâtikawin, êh-itâcik ôhi nâpêsisah, êh-wayêsimâcik, êh-pê-kîwêcik, êh-pê-tapasîcik.
sentences.text: ê-itâcik ôhi nâpêsisa ê-wayêsimâcik ê-pê-kîwêcik ê-pê-tapasîcik
sentences.english: When we have found water, you will be fetched,” they told him, deceiving him, for they were going to flee for home.
So they all stayed alive and reached their village.

sentences.original: awa wîhkasko-kisêyin oskotâkay wâpôwayân nistomitanaw nîsohayiwâk tahtwayak, êkosi nama nânitaw mâ-misiwêw êh-pikwâhoht.
sentences.text: awa wîhkasko-kisêyin oskotâkay wâpôwayân nistomitanaw nîsohayiwâk tahtwayak êkosi nama nânitaw mâ-misiwê ê-pikwâhoht
sentences.english: Sweet-Grass'  coat and blanket had thirty-two bullet-holes, but in no spot was he wounded.
sentences.footnote: LB on {tahtwayak}:  The word “it was pierced” was not spoken, but supplied by gesture.

sentences.english: So goes this story.
It is not old
Perhaps a hundred years.
